H0.text: Cells are small, which made it difficult for scientists to view them without a microscope, even though the development of the microscope enabled them to see cells for the first time.

H1.text: Cells are alive was why it was difficult to view cells without a microscope, until the development of the microscope allowed scientists to see cells for the first time.

H2.text: Cells move quickly, making it difficult to view them without a microscope, until the microscopeâ€™s development enabled scientists to see cells for the first time.

H3.text: Cells have an electrical charge, which made them difficult to view without a microscope, until the development of the microscope allowed scientists to see them for the first time.

A4.text: In his book Micrographia he coined the term cell (from Latin cellula, meaning 'small room') since they resembled the cells of a monastery.

A5.text: Robert Hooke discovered cells in cork, then in living plant tissue using an early microscope.
